block.p: Troops Try to Stabilize Rebel Areas in Iraq American and Iraqi forces battled their way into Samarra, saying that they had taken control of more than half the town and that they had killed more than 100 insurgents. The assault represented the first major effort to reclaim areas that have fallen into the hands of rebels ahead of the scheduled nationwide elections.
Citing the ongoing danger and unpredictability of the Iraqi insurgency, news organizations from France, Germany, Italy and other European nations have recently scaled back their presence in Iraq.

One of the two Italian aid workers freed after three weeks in captivity in Iraq said the fight against American troops and their allies there was not terrorism but legitimate resistance to occupation.

Bombing in Pakistan Mosque Pakistani officials said that a powerful explosion detonated by a suspected suicide bomber ripped through a Shiite mosque filled with hundreds of worshippers in the eastern city of Sialkot, killing at least 23 people and wounding more than 60.
Reinforcing Qaeda's Message An audio taped message by Al Qaeda's second-ranking leader calls on young Muslims around the world to ''carry on the fight'' if the group's leaders are killed or captured.
More Deaths in Gaza Offensive Israel sent more tanks and armored vehicles into the Jabaliya refugee camp in Gaza City. At least eight Palestinians were killed and 17 wounded in two missile strikes.

Bush Attacks Kerry, Who Has New Confidence President Bush ripped into Senator John Kerry as an equivocator who denigrates American troops and who would subject the nation's national security decisions to vetoes ''by countries like France.'' Mr. Kerry, with strategists saying he had helped himself in the first of three debates, acted at campaign rallies in Florida as if he had taken the upper hand.
Eruption at Mount St. Helens A series of earthquakes at Mount St. Helens, the most active volcano in the lower 48 states, culminated in an explosion that sent a plume of steam and ash into the sky.

Judge Drops Sniper Charges A Virginia judge dismissed all charges against John A. Muhammad in the killing of a woman during Washington-area sniper attacks in 2002. He has already been sentenced to die in another case.
New Battle on the Voting Front A check box about citizenship on registration forms has touched off a battle over voting rights in Florida.
NASA Delays Shuttle Plans NASA has abandoned plans to resume flying the space shuttle next March because of the effect of four hurricanes on space agency centers and work schedules.

Terror Watch List in Jeopardy Efforts to create a master terrorist ''watch list,'' a top priority for the Bush administration, are lagging badly because of bureaucratic problems, according to a report by the department's inspector general.

Fewer Unwed Mothers In New York State New York State has achieved sustained declines in out-of-wedlock births for the first time in a generation, and from 1999 to 2002 experienced the greatest numerical reduction in births to unwed mothers of any state, state officials said.

New Commercial Waste Plan New York City's commercial waste will be directed to a marine transfer station on the West Side of Manhattan instead of being shipped through the Bronx and Brooklyn, the Bloomberg administration said.
Casino Workers Begin Strike About 10,000 workers struck 7 of Atlantic City's 12 casinos, and the management took over as waiters, bartenders and hotel workers.
Chairman Defends Release The chairman of a city commission that granted Guy J. Velella an early release from jail said he did not regret the decision.

Rockers Start Pro-Kerry Tour Bruce Springsteen, R.E.M., Dave Matthews, the Dixie Chicks, Pearl Jam, Bonnie Raitt and John Mellencamp began a 10-day tour of swing states to urge support for Senator John Kerry.
Ford Plans Emission Cuts Top executives at Ford have privately endorsed an aggressive goal of reining in global warming emissions from their vehicles by 2030.
PeopleSoft Fires Its Chief PeopleSoft fired its president and chief executive, Craig A. Conway, increasing the likelihood that it would be taken over by Oracle.
A Tentative Deal for US Airways US Airways and its pilots union reached tentative agreement on $300 million in annual wage and benefit cuts.
Editorials: How to save Social Security; confronting Tom DeLay.
Columns: David Brooks, Nicholas D. Kristof.
